column2: ROUGH RIDERS IN THE SADDLE
column3: ROUGH RIDERS IN THE SADDLE

column2: He no doubt would bring food of some kind with him.
column3: He no doubt would bring food of some kind with him.

column2: The fire would be ready and thus no time would be lost in preparing the first meal of the day, which, in this case, would be breakfast, dinner and supper all in one.
column3: The fire would be ready and thus no time would be lost in preparing the first meal of the day, which, in this case, would be breakfast, dinner and supper all in one.

column2: The boys awaited the guide's approach with impatience, some pacing back and forth, while others coaxed the fire into a roaring blaze, at the same time confiding to each other how hungry they were.
column3: The boys awaited the guide's approach with impatience, some pacing back and forth, while others coaxed the fire into a roaring blaze, at the same time confiding to each other how hungry they were.

column2: It was a gladsome sound to this band of hungry boys, whose ordinarily healthy appetites, under the bracing mountain air and the long fast, had taken on what the Professor described as a "razor edge."
column3: It was a gladsome sound to this band of hungry boys, whose ordinarily healthy appetites, under the bracing mountain air and the long fast, had taken on what the Professor described as a "razor edge."

column2: Now you may go, he nodded.
column3: Now you may go, he nodded.

column2: With a shout, the boys dashed pell-mell to meet the pack train, and, falling in behind the slow-moving burros, urged them on with derisive shouts and sundry resounding slaps on the animals' flanks.
column3: With a shout, the boys dashed pell mell to meet the pack train, and, falling in behind the slow moving burros, urged them on with derisive shouts and sundry resounding slaps on the animals' flanks.

column2: Had anything to eat! asked the guide.
column3: Had anything to eat! asked the guide.

column2: Not enough to give us indigestion, answered Ned.
column3: Not enough to give us indigestion, answered Ned.

column2: Cold water is the most nourishing thing we've touched since last night.
column3: Cold water is the most nourishing thing we've touched since last night.

column2: But I left you a rabbit.	But I left you a rabbit.
Didn't you find it?"
column3: Didn't you find it?"

column2: We did not.	We did not.
It must have come to life some time during the night and dug its way out," laughed Tad.
column3: It must have come to life some time during the night and dug its way out," laughed Tad.

column2: And we've got a surprise for you, announced Stacy, swelling with pride.
column3: And we've got a surprise for you, announced Stacy, swelling with pride.

column2: You'll see when you get to camp, answered Chunky.
column3: You'll see when you get to camp, answered Chunky.

column2: I don't need guns to hunt with.	I don't need guns to hunt with.
A stout club for mine."
column3: A stout club for mine."

column2: By the time the meal was ready the tents had been pitched and the boys had returned from the spring, rubbing their faces with their coarse towels, their cheeks glowing and their eyes sparkling in anticipation of the feast.
column3: By the time the meal was ready the tents had been pitched and the boys had returned from the spring, rubbing their faces with their coarse towels, their cheeks glowing and their eyes sparkling in anticipation of the feast.

column2: Chunky reached the table first, greedily surveying what had been placed on it.
column3: Chunky reached the table first, greedily surveying what had been placed on it.

column2: Hooray, fellows! he shouted.
column3: Hooray, fellows! he shouted.

column2: What do you think of that?"
column3: What do you think of that?"

column2: Honey?	Honey?
Why, Mr. Thomas, where did you get honey?" asked Walter.
column3: Why, mr Thomas, where did you get honey?" asked Walter.

column2: Found a bee tree on my way back, and cut it down.	Found a bee tree on my way back, and cut it down.
We'll take all chances, advised Ned.
column3: We'll take all chances, advised Ned.

column2: But what's this!	But what's this!
It looks like jam."
column3: It looks like jam."

column2: Yes; wild plum jam, answered the guide.
column3: Yes; wild plum jam, answered the guide.

column2: Now, fall to, young gentlemen, directed the Professor.
column3: Now, fall to, young gentlemen, directed the Professor.

column2: I am free to admit that I am hungry, too.	I am free to admit that I am hungry, too.
I think I shall help myself to some of that wild plum jam and biscuit, first It reminds me of old times.
column3: I think I shall help myself to some of that wild plum jam and biscuit, first It reminds me of old times.

column2: We sometimes had jam when I was with the German----"
column3: We sometimes had jam when I was with the German----"

column2: Army, added Ned.
column3: Army, added Ned.

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: Chunky did even better than that.
column3: Chunky did even better than that.

column2: He buried his biscuit under a layer of jam, over which he spread a thick coating of honey.
column3: He buried his biscuit under a layer of jam, over which he spread a thick coating of honey.

column2: Ned fixed him with a stern eye.
column3: Ned fixed him with a stern eye.

column2: Remember, sir, that a certain amount of dignity befits the office of president of the Pony Riders Club, he said.
column3: Remember, sir, that a certain amount of dignity befits the office of president of the Pony Riders Club, he said.

column2: Chunky colored.
column3: Chunky colored.

column2: It's good, anyway.

column2: Then, I think I'll try some myself, announced Ned, helping himself liberally to the honey and jam.
column3: Then, I think I'll try some myself, announced Ned, helping himself liberally to the honey and jam.

column2: I'd lose my dignity for a mouthful of that, any day, he decided after having sampled the combination. "President Brown, I withdraw my criticism.
column3: I'd lose my dignity for a mouthful of that, any day, he decided after having sampled the combination. "President Brown, I withdraw my criticism.

column2: I offer you my humble apologies.
column3: I offer you my humble apologies.

column2: Next thing we know you'll be providing us with bear steak."
column3: Next thing we know you'll be providing us with bear steak."

column2: Are there bears up here?
column3: Are there bears up here?

column2: I reckon there are, smiled the guide.
column3: I reckon there are, smiled the guide.

column2: We are in the bear country now.	We are in the bear country now.
I came near losing my life too, and----"
column3: I came near losing my life too, and----"

column2: A cave? interrupted Tad.
column3: A cave? interrupted Tad.

column2: Yes, the country is full of caves.	Yes, the country is full of caves.
Besides this, there are many abandoned mines up the range further.
column3: Besides this, there are many abandoned mines up the range further.

column2: All you want.	All you want.
This announcement filled the boys with excitement.
column3: This announcement filled the boys with excitement.

column2: What I want to know, is, when do we go hunting? asked Ned.
column3: What I want to know, is, when do we go hunting? asked Ned.

column2: That depends.	That depends.
Perhaps Tuesday.
column3: Perhaps Tuesday.

column2: We shall need a dog.
column3: We shall need a dog.

column2: But I know an old settler who will lend us his dog, if it is not out.
column3: But I know an old settler who will lend us his dog, if it is not out.

column2: Of course, dogs can't follow the trail of an animal as well, now, as they could with snow on the ground.
column3: Of course, dogs can't follow the trail of an animal as well, now, as they could with snow on the ground.

column2: But this dog, you will find, is a wonder.
column3: But this dog, you will find, is a wonder.

column2: I think I'll ride my own pony and let the dog walk, announced Ned.
column3: I think I'll ride my own pony and let the dog walk, announced Ned.

column2: Supper having been finished, the party gathered about the camp fire for their evening chat, after which, admonishing Stacy to keep within his tent and not to go borrowing trouble, the boys turned in for a sound sleep.
column3: Supper having been finished, the party gathered about the camp fire for their evening chat, after which, admonishing Stacy to keep within his tent and not to go borrowing trouble, the boys turned in for a sound sleep.

column2: As yet, they had been unable to attempt any fancy riding with their ponies, owing to the rugged nature of the country through which they had been journeying.
column3: As yet, they had been unable to attempt any fancy riding with their ponies, owing to the rugged nature of the country through which they had been journeying.

column2: The guide said that, by making a detour in their journey that day, they would cross table lands several acres in extent and covered with grass.
column3: The guide said that, by making a detour in their journey that day, they would cross table lands several acres in extent and covered with grass.

column2: The trail is so plainly marked that he can't miss it."
column3: The trail is so plainly marked that he can't miss it."

column2: The boys were now all anxiety to start, while the ponies, after their Sunday rest, were almost as full of life as were their owners.
column3: The boys were now all anxiety to start, while the ponies, after their Sunday rest, were almost as full of life as were their owners.

column2: The little animals were becoming more sure-footed every day, and Ned said that, before the trip was finished, "Jimmie" would be able to walk a slack rope.
column3: The little animals were becoming more sure footed every day, and Ned said that, before the trip was finished, "Jimmie" would be able to walk a slack rope.

column2: An early start was made, so that the party reached the promised table lands shortly before ten o'clock in the forenoon.
column3: An early start was made, so that the party reached the promised table lands shortly before ten o'clock in the forenoon.

column2: A temporary camp was quickly pitched.
column3: A temporary camp was quickly pitched.

column2: At their urgent request, Professor Zepplin told the boys to go ahead and enjoy themselves.
column3: At their urgent request, Professor Zepplin told the boys to go ahead and enjoy themselves.

column2: I guess I had better go along to see that you do not.
column3: I guess I had better go along to see that you do not.

column2: They assured him that nothing was further from their intention, and quickly casting aside guns and cartridge belts, they threw themselves into their saddles again for a jolly romp.
column3: They assured him that nothing was further from their intention, and quickly casting aside guns and cartridge belts, they threw themselves into their saddles again for a jolly romp.

column2: The great, green field, surrounded on all sides by tall trees, made the place an ideal one for their purpose.
column3: The great, green field, surrounded on all sides by tall trees, made the place an ideal one for their purpose.

column2: Suppose we start with a race?	Suppose we start with a race?
We'll race the length of the field and back.
column3: We'll race the length of the field and back.

column2: We'll do it three times, and the one who wins two times out of three will be it."
column3: We'll do it three times, and the one who wins two times out of three will be it."

column2: To this all agreed.
column3: To this all agreed.

column2: Walter Perkins won the heat.
column3: Walter Perkins won the heat.

column2: The next two heats were different.
column3: The next two heats were different.

column2: This time the battle lay between Tad Butler and Ned Rector.
column3: This time the battle lay between Tad Butler and Ned Rector.

column2: It was a beautiful race, the little Indian ponies seeming to enter thoroughly into the spirit of the contest, stretching themselves out to their full lengths, and, with heads on a level with their backs, fairly flew across the great plot of green.
column3: It was a beautiful race, the little Indian ponies seeming to enter thoroughly into the spirit of the contest, stretching themselves out to their full lengths, and, with heads on a level with their backs, fairly flew across the great plot of green.

column2: Up to within a moment of the finish of the second heat the two ponies were racing neck and neck.
column3: Up to within a moment of the finish of the second heat the two ponies were racing neck and neck.

column2: Tad hitched in his saddle a little, throwing the greater part of his weight on the stirrups.
column3: Tad hitched in his saddle a little, throwing the greater part of his weight on the stirrups.

column2: He slapped Texas sharply on the flank with the flat of his hand.
column3: He slapped Texas sharply on the flank with the flat of his hand.

column2: Texas seemed to leap clear of the ground, planting himself on all fours just over the line, the winner by a neck.
column3: Texas seemed to leap clear of the ground, planting himself on all fours just over the line, the winner by a neck.

column2: The third heat was merely a repetition of the second.
column3: The third heat was merely a repetition of the second.

column2: All agreed that Tad's superior horsemanship, alone, had won the race for him.
column3: All agreed that Tad's superior horsemanship, alone, had won the race for him.

column2: Ned took his defeat good-naturedly.
column3: Ned took his defeat good naturedly.

column2: By this time, the boys had come to feel fully as much at home in the saddle as they formerly had been out of it.
column3: By this time, the boys had come to feel fully as much at home in the saddle as they formerly had been out of it.

column2: Even Stacy Brown, though he did not sit his saddle with the same grace that marked the riding of Tad Butler and Ned Rector, more practiced horsemen, was nevertheless no mean rider.
column3: Even Stacy Brown, though he did not sit his saddle with the same grace that marked the riding of Tad Butler and Ned Rector, more practiced horsemen, was nevertheless no mean rider.

column2: I'll show you, promised Tad.
column3: I'll show you, promised Tad.

column2: Galloping into camp the boy fetched his sombrero, which he carried well out into the field and tossed away.
column3: Galloping into camp the boy fetched his sombrero, which he carried well out into the field and tossed away.

column2: All at once he dropped to the saddle and slipped the left foot from the stirrup.
column3: All at once he dropped to the saddle and slipped the left foot from the stirrup.

column2: Grasping the pommel with the left hand, he appeared to dive head first toward the ground.
column3: Grasping the pommel with the left hand, he appeared to dive head first toward the ground.

column2: Huh!	Huh!
That's nothing.
column3: That's nothing.

column2: I can do that myself," he grunted.
column3: I can do that myself," he grunted.

column2: I've seen them do that in the wild west shows too many times not to know how myself.
column3: I've seen them do that in the wild west shows too many times not to know how myself.

column2: Walter smiled, with a twinkle in his eyes.
column3: Walter smiled, with a twinkle in his eyes.

column2: Why not show us, then? he said.
column3: Why not show us, then? he said.

column2: I will, replied Chunky, confidently.
column3: I will, replied Chunky, confidently.

column2: Got your life insured? asked Ned.
column3: Got your life insured? asked Ned.

column2: If you haven't I would advise you to go easy.	If you haven't I would advise you to go easy.
Don't you worry about me, Ned Rector.	Don't you worry about me, Ned Rector.
Guess I know how to ride.

column2: Let me have that hat, Tad," he demanded as the latter came trotting up to the group.
column3: Let me have that hat, Tad," he demanded as the latter came trotting up to the group.

column2: Stacy, his face flushed, determination plainly showing in his eyes, stretched forth his hand for the sombrero.
column3: Stacy, his face flushed, determination plainly showing in his eyes, stretched forth his hand for the sombrero.

column2: Riding bravely out into the field, he tossed it to the ground.
column3: Riding bravely out into the field, he tossed it to the ground.

column2: Stacy dismounted and removed the hat carefully to one side.
column3: Stacy dismounted and removed the hat carefully to one side.

column2: I couldn't get it," explained Chunky.

column2: Why don't you move the pony?	Why don't you move the pony?
You don't have to move the hat, you ninny."
column3: You don't have to move the hat, you ninny."

column2: Be careful, Chunky, warned Walter.
column3: Be careful, Chunky, warned Walter.

column2: He's got to learn, declared Tad.
column3: He's got to learn, declared Tad.

column2: Then Chunky essayed the feat.
column3: Then Chunky essayed the feat.

column2: At the moment when he freed his left foot from the stirrup, he threw his body sharply to the right, reaching for the hat without taking the precaution to grasp the pommel.
column3: At the moment when he freed his left foot from the stirrup, he threw his body sharply to the right, reaching for the hat without taking the precaution to grasp the pommel.

column2: As a result, instead of stopping when he reached the hat, the boy kept on going.
column3: As a result, instead of stopping when he reached the hat, the boy kept on going.

column2: Fortunately, his right foot freed itself from the stirrup at the same time, or there might have been a different ending.
column3: Fortunately, his right foot freed itself from the stirrup at the same time, or there might have been a different ending.

column2: Chunky turned a double somersault, lay still for a moment, then struggled up, rubbing his body gingerly, as the rest of the party came hurrying up to him.
column3: Chunky turned a double somersault, lay still for a moment, then struggled up, rubbing his body gingerly, as the rest of the party came hurrying up to him.

column2: Are you hurt? asked Tad apprehensively.
